text:
Canal Street, west from the southern end of Thompson Street, prior to the digging of the Independent (municipal) Subway and the south-bound extension of Sixth Avenue. The first step taken will be the demolition of all the buildings on the north side of Canal Street from Thompson to Sullivan Streets.

1926.

(1) Canal Street, north side, from Thompson Street to West Broadway (formerly South Fifth Avenue), seen from the eastern end of Laight Street. September 24, 1927. P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, a year later, seen from York Street at West Broadway, across the site of the buildings between York and Canal Streets. Canal Street is being supported on stilts which the construction of the subway goes on underneath; the view at the left is practically north along the future east side of Sixth Avenue. Krist's Bakery, the light house with the dormer window, is No. 387 Canal Street. In the background of both these views may be seen the steeple of St. Alphonsus' Roman Catholic Church. October 10, 1928. P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same as No. 2, as seen from Sixth Ave. Extension at West Broadway. Elevated shown is the Sixth Ave. line. March 19, 1932. P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same as No. 2, as seen from Sixth Ave. Extension at West Broadway. Elevated shown is the Sixth Ave. line. March 19, 1932. P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same as No. 2, as seen from Sixth Ave. Extension at West Broadway. Elevated shown is the Sixth Ave. line. March 19, 1932. P. L. Sperr.

(1) Canal Street, north side, west from Thompson Street and Sixth Avenue Extension. All the buildings from Thompson to Sullivan Streets have been demolished, and the west side of Sullivan Street, from Canal to Grand Streets, will form the west side of this part of Sixth Avenue. The eight-story Peter Frasse & Company building stands at the N.W. corner of Canal and Sullivan Streets. The ten-story Powell Chocolate factory, on the N.E. corner, has just been demolished. December 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same at a later date and showing a view northward on the new Sixth Ave. Extension. On the left appears a portion of Varick Street.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Canal Street, north side, west from Thompson Street and Sixth Avenue Extension. All the buildings from Thompson to Sullivan Streets have been demolished, and the west side of Sullivan Street, from Canal to Grand Streets, will form the west side of this part of Sixth Avenue. The eight-story Peter Frasse & Company building stands at the N.W. corner of Canal and Sullivan Streets. The ten-story Powell Chocolate factory, on the N.E. corner, has just been demolished. December 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same at a later date and showing a view northward on the new Sixth Ave. Extension. On the left appears a portion of Varick Street.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
4-10 Thompson Street, adjoining and north of the N.E. corner of Canal Street. Nos. 8-10 is the St. Alphonsus R.C. Church, with the Parochial School (Nos. 4-6) adjoining. This view is as seen from the new Sixth Ave. Extension and during its construction period.
October 19, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, during demolition period.
September 9, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, slightly more extensive; at a later date, as seen from the S.W. corner of Laight at Varick St's.
June 3, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

St. Alphonsus (Roman Catholic) Church and Rectory, 310-314 and 308 West Broadway (formerly 228 and 234 South Fifth Avenue), west side, between Canal and Grand Streets. The Hall (former school) is next door (off the picture at the right) at No. 316-328 West Broadway. This church was organized in 1847; but the present buildings were erected since, though probably not long after 1870, when South Fifth Avenue was created by widening Laurens Street from Canal to Amity Streets (West 3rd Street), and cutting it through the block to Washington Square.

March 27, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

370-372 Canal Street, south side, east of West Broadway.

1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

Former home of the People's Bank, 395 Canal Street at the N.E. corner of Thompson Street, and the gap adjoining, where No. 391 stood. The timbers buttress the east wall of No. 395 and the west wall of 389 against each other.

March 19, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

Bookshop at 383 Canal Street, adjoining N.W. corner of West Broadway. May 19, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

2, 4-6, 8-10 Thompson Street, at, adjoining and north of Canal Street, showing the parochial school and back door of St. Alphonsus Roman Catholic Church.

May 19, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Canal Street (left) south side, east from West Broadway.

June 11, 1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

(1)
391-387 Canal Street, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of Thompson Street. Krist's Bakery is located at No. 387.
October 21, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, at a later date. In the rear of the houses appears part of St. Alphonsus (R.C.) Church, situated on West Broadway, between Canal and Grand Streets.
May 20, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

No. 1.

Canal St., south side, east from West Broadway (right, not shown), to Broadway (left) and across Church St., showing a clearance at the S. W. corner of the latter point, over which towers the upper portion of No. 401 Broadway.

May 7, 1938.

P. L. Sperr,

No. 2.

A view in the opposite direction (westward), showing the new Post Office site under preparation on the west side of Church St. The Sixth Avenue elevated line appears at the right running at this point on West Broadway. To the extreme left, one sees a portion of the Telephone Co. Bldg.

P. L. Sperr.

March 11, 1938.

No. 1.

Canal St., south side, east from West Broadway (right, not shown), to Broadway (left) and across Church St., showing a clearance at the S. W. corner of the latter point, over which towers the upper portion of No. 401 Broadway.

May 7, 1938.

P. L. Sperr,

No. 2.

A view in the opposite direction (westward), showing the new Post Office site under preparation on the west side of Church St. The Sixth Avenue elevated line appears at the right running at this point on West Broadway. To the extreme left, one sees a portion of the Telephone Co. Bldg.

P. L. Sperr.

March 11, 1938.

West Broadway, east side, south from a point slightly north of Canal Street and across same, showing above the Sixth Ave. Elevated structure the New York Telephone Building.

May 7, 1938

P. L. Sperr

West Broadway (Sixth Ave. Elevated line thereon), north from Canal Street, showing on the west side of the former, St. Alphonsus Roman Catholic Church.
No. 2 includes the 4 story structure (No. 375 Canal Street and No. 301 West Broadway), at the N.E. corner.

May 2, 1938.

P. L. Sperr.

West Broadway (Sixth Ave. Elevated line thereon), north from Canal Street, showing on the west side of the former, St. Alphonsus Roman Catholic Church.
No. 2 includes the 4 story structure (No. 375 Canal Street and No. 301 West Broadway), at the N.E. corner.

May 2, 1938.

P. L. Sperr.

West Broadway, west side, north from a point (St. Alphonsus Roman Catholic Church Hall), between Canal and Grand Streets, showing an elevated station at the latter point. The one (---) structure seen in the foreground is at the S.W. corner, while across the roof of same, appears a five story tenement, No. 50-52 Grand Street at the N.W. corner. The elevated line overshadowing this thoroughfare is the Sixth Ave. system.
May 7, 1938.

Canal Street, at, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of West Broadway as photographed from the S.W. corner.

A similar view as this was prohibited previously, as the old Sixth Avenue "El" which ran on West Broadway obstructed the view. Recently this was razed in its entirety.

View 1: March 19, 1939
View 2: May 19, 1939

P. L. Sperr

Canal Street, at, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of West Broadway as photographed from the S.W. corner.

A similar view as this was prohibited previously, as the old Sixth Avenue "El" which ran on West Broadway obstructed the view. Recently this was razed in its entirety.

View 1: March 19, 1939
View 2: May 19, 1939

P. L. Sperr

West Broadway, west side, south from and across Canal Street. In the center and on a diagonal runs the Sixth Avenue Extension. This forms the far side of the triangular plot utilized as a gasoline station.

July 25, 1939.

P. L. Sperr

West Broadway, north from and across Canal Street, showing the thoroughfare subsequent to demolition of the Sixth Avenue "El."

On the west side of same, between Canal and Broome Street's is St. Alphonsus R. C. Church, Rectory and Hall. This area is shown solely in View 2.

View 1: March 19, 1939
View 2: July 12, 1939

P. L. Sperr

West Broadway, north from and across Canal Street, showing the thoroughfare subsequent to demolition of the Sixth Avenue "El."

On the west side of same, between Canal and Broome Street's is St. Alphonsus R. C. Church, Rectory and Hall. This area is shown solely in View 2.

View 1: March 19, 1939
View 2: July 12, 1939

P. L. Sperr

West Broadway, north from a point between Canal and Grand Street's and across the latter.

View 1 emphasizes the walled yard of the Railway Express Agency on the east side of this thorough-fare. The not shown St. Alphonsus Church (left) faces this.

Views 2 and 3 are from a vantage point closer to Grand Street. Note in the earlier view the iron standards that formerly supported the old Sixth Avenue "El."

In the background, beyond Washington Square appears the apartment structure, No. 1 Fifth Avenue and the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. tower.

Views 1, 2: May 19, 1939
View 3: March 19, 1939

P. L. Sperr

View 1 2 - #2117 (neg)
3 - Neg # 218
